defect.para: The vehicles involved are AmTran RE model school buses 3302, 3505, and 3708 built from May 28, 1996 through October 21, 1996.

The air/spring actuated parking brake chambers manufactured by Midland, with date code 145B6K, were filled with the wrong lubrication by the supplier. The improper lubricant can cause the seals within the chamber to fail and result in loss of air. If air pressure drops below 55 psi and the operator does not heed the low air pressure warning and continues to drive, the parking brake may start to apply. Continuing to drive in this condition will cause the parking brake lining to overheat and have premature wear. A parking brake that has overheated and has premature wear may not operate properly when the bus is parked and the brake is applied.

warning.para: A spring brake contains a very powerful compression spring. Failure to comply with all of the following instructions may result in forceful release of the double diaphragm spring chamber and its contents which could cause death, severe personal injury and/or property damage.

step1.para: Block wheels to prevent vehicle from moving during inspection.
Locate the air parking brake chamber (A) that is attached to a bracket on the side of the transmission (under the vehicle). Refer to Figure 1.
Locate serial number on case of air chamber.

warning.para: Do not remove cover. Serious injury or death could occur due to release of powerful compression.

step1.para: Use a mirror if necessary to view serial number.
If date code 145B6K is present, the chamber must be replaced. Proceed to repair procedures. If date code 145B6K is not present, no further action is necessary. Fill out and return reply card.
Always block wheels to prevent vehicle rollaway when replacing spring brake assembly.

warning.para: The spring brake chamber portion of the assembly has been sealed for your protection. There are no useable service parts inside the spring brake chamber. If the date code on the spring brake chamber is 145B6K, replace the complete chamber as outlined in this section. Never attempt to disassemble the spring brake chamber as serious personal injury, death and/or property damage could result from accidental sudden release of the powerful compression spring.

step1.para: Never strike any part of the spring brake with a hammer or any other heavy object; structural damage may result.
Do not drop the spring brake, as the jar may release the spring.

svcsubproc.title: Removal of Spring Parking Brake Chamber

warning.para: Always cage the compression spring with the cage nut located on the threaded portion of chamber shaft. Do not rely on air pressure to keep spring compressed. Failure to cage the compression spring may result in forceful release of the compression spring which could cause death, severe personal injury and/or property damage.

step1.para: Block wheels to prevent vehicle from moving.
Release parking brake with valve on dash if air pressure is sufficient in system.
Cage spring brake by tightening cage nut (F) to relieve spring pressure. If air pressure is used to compress the spring, do not tighten the cage nut more than finger tight.
Release air pressure to spring brake chamber by applying parking brake with valve on dash.
Remove air line from spring brake chamber.
Remove the pin (E) that fastens the spring brake push rod clevis to the brake lever (D).
Remove the two nuts and washers (C) that fasten the chamber assembly (A) to the mounting bracket (B).

svcsubproc.title: Installation of Spring Parking Brake Chamber

step1.para: Inspect parking brake linings for abnormal wear and replace as necessary.
Pin (E) the spring brake pushrod clevis to the brake lever (D).
Fasten the chamber assembly (A) to the mounting bracket. Tighten the two mounting nuts (C) to 105 - 125 ft-lbs. (142 - 169 Nm).
Install air line to the spring brake chamber (A).
Uncage compression spring nut (F).

important.para: After re-assembly, check for proper spring brake operation. Check brake adjustment.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. As a precaution, you should not operate any of the vehicles subject to this recall campaign until they have been inspected for the presence of the nut assembled to the pinch bolt. In the event that the nut is missing, repairs must be made before the vehicle is driven. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
